key_title: Key to the genera of Pittosporaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Walsh, N.G.; Albrecht, D.E.
source.title: Pittosporaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G.; Albrecht, D.E. (1996). Pittosporaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Twiners (sometimes subshrubby); flowers pendent; fruit more or less cylindric, a berry or thin-walled capsule
Trees or shrubs, sometimes prostrate or procumbent, but never twining; flowers opening widely; fruit a hard, 2-valved, rarely 3-valved capsule, or if somewhat papery, then strongly flattened
Fruit a thin-walled capsule; Grampians only
Flowers white, cream or yellow, sometimes streaked mauve; anthers shorter than filaments, arranged all around ovary; habit various
Flowers blue-violet, 2 cm wide or more; stamens with anthers longer than filaments, turned to one side of ovary, opening via terminal pores; slender, erect subshrub to c. 50 cm high
Flowers axillary or terminal, solitary or in umbel-like cymes; corolla somewhat tubular in lower part; capsule biconvex to globose
Flowers in terminal panicles; petals spreading from base; capsule obovate to obcordate, strongly flattened; shrubs often spinose
Fruit woody, valves rounded; seeds with a viscid coating; erect shrubs or trees with leaves 3 cm long or more
Fruit rather thin-walled, each valve impressed along the median line; seeds dry; prostrate or procumbent shrubs with leaves to c. 2 cm long
